supporting_theories: Cognitive Load Theory (Sweller) — explanation must be comprehensible

global_governance.escalation_policy: Failure at any section -> escalate to supervisor

sections.theoretical_basis: Legal Positivism & Jurisdictional Sovereignty + GDPR Territorial Scope (Art. 3) + POPIA (South Africa Protection of Personal Information Act)
what_to_measure: Prohibited data practices under applicable law

measurement_principles.no_legal_vacuum: System must never operate without a positively identified legal regime
measurement_principles.strictest_regime: When signals conflict, apply the most restrictive applicable law
measurement_principles.explicit_identification: Jurisdiction must be positively determined, never assumed

decision_rules.hard_veto: If legal regime cannot be determined → SYSTEM HALT (absolute prohibition)
decision_rules.conflict_resolution: If tenant jurisdiction differs from user jurisdiction → apply stricter regime
decision_rules.default_rule: If signals are fully obscured → apply Global_Restrictive_Baseline or FAIL

validation_criteria: Jurisdiction positively identified from valid signals
Jurisdiction database is reachable and current
Legal regime locked for session duration
All mandatory requirements extracted
No prohibited practices in proposed action
sections.description: Framework defining how to identify and lock the applicable legal jurisdiction before any data processing or pedagogical action proceeds.

sections.theoretical_basis: Purpose Limitation Principle (GDPR Art. 5(1)(b)) + OECD Privacy Guidelines (Purpose Specification Principle) + Fair Information Practice Principles (FIPPs)
what_to_measure: Declared data purpose existence and clarity

measurement_principles.declared_first: Purpose must be declared before any data collection begins
measurement_principles.alignment_check: Each proposed action is checked against declared purpose
measurement_principles.no_scope_creep: Data cannot be repurposed without new declaration and consent

decision_rules.purpose_match: Action purpose must fall within declared scope boundaries
decision_rules.purpose_drift: If action purpose diverges from declared purpose → DENY unless re-declared
decision_rules.continued_compliance: Periodic re-validation that processing still serves original purpose
decision_rules.scope_violation: Any use beyond declared scope → immediate QUARANTINE

validation_criteria: Declared purpose exists and is specific
Proposed action falls within declared purpose scope
No function creep detected
Continued compliance verified for ongoing processing
sections.description: Framework defining how to enforce the purpose limitation principle — ensuring data is collected and processed only for declared, legitimate purposes.

sections.theoretical_basis: Informed Consent Doctrine (Bioethics → Data Ethics) + GDPR Consent Requirements (Art. 6(1)(a), Art. 7) + Belmont Report (Respect for Persons)
what_to_measure: Contextual pressure indicators (dark patterns, power imbalances)

measurement_principles.freely_given: Consent must be voluntary, without coercion or undue influence
measurement_principles.specific: Consent must cover the specific processing being proposed
measurement_principles.informed: Data subject must understand what they are consenting to
measurement_principles.unambiguous: Consent must be a clear affirmative act
measurement_principles.withdrawable: Right to withdraw must be as easy as giving consent

decision_rules.no_consent: If no consent record exists → DENY action
decision_rules.scope_mismatch: If consent does not cover proposed action → DENY and request new consent
decision_rules.expired_consent: If consent has expired or been revoked → DENY until renewed
decision_rules.pressure_detected: If contextual pressure indicators found → QUARANTINE for review
decision_rules.minor_protection: If data subject is a minor → apply enhanced consent requirements
decision_rules.refusal_blocked: If meaningful refusal is not available → DENY (consent is not freely given)

validation_criteria: Valid consent record exists for data subject
Consent scope covers the specific proposed action
Consent is temporally valid (not expired or revoked)
Consent meets policy requirements (age, language, format)
No contextual pressure indicators detected
Meaningful refusal pathway is available and accessible
sections.description: Framework defining how to validate that informed, voluntary, uncoerced consent exists for all data processing actions, with scope coverage and temporal validity.

sections.theoretical_basis: Algorithmic Fairness (Barocas & Selbst, 2016) + Rawls' Theory of Justice (Difference Principle) + Anti-Discrimination Law (EU, ZA, US frameworks)
what_to_measure: Protected attribute presence in input features

measurement_principles.demographic_parity: Outcomes should not vary significantly across protected groups
measurement_principles.individual_fairness: Similar individuals should receive similar treatment
measurement_principles.proxy_vigilance: Features highly correlated with protected attributes are treated as proxies
measurement_principles.cumulative_tracking: Disparity must be tracked across multiple decisions, not just single instances

decision_rules.protected_attribute_detected: If protected attributes found in decision features → require justification
decision_rules.proxy_detected: If high-correlation proxy detected → treat as protected attribute
decision_rules.differential_treatment: If treatment differs significantly across groups → QUARANTINE for review
decision_rules.unjustified_disparity: If disparity exists without pedagogical justification → DENY
decision_rules.cumulative_threshold: If cumulative disparity score exceeds threshold → trigger remediation

validation_criteria: All input features scanned for protected attributes
Proxy features identified and flagged
Differential treatment analysis completed
Justification provided for any attribute-correlated decision
Cumulative disparity within acceptable bounds
sections.description: Framework defining how to detect and prevent discriminatory outcomes, ensure equitable treatment across protected attributes, and flag cumulative disparities.

sections.theoretical_basis: Right to Explanation (GDPR Art. 22, Recital 71) + Explainable AI (XAI) Principles (DARPA, 2016) + Procedural Justice Theory (Tyler, 1990)
what_to_measure: Rationale fidelity to actual decision logic

measurement_principles.causal_fidelity: Explanation must reflect actual decision logic, not post-hoc rationalization
measurement_principles.audience_appropriate: Explanation must be comprehensible to affected party (age, expertise, language)
measurement_principles.contestation_right: Every automated decision must have a pathway for human challenge
measurement_principles.trace_completeness: Full causal chain from input to output must be reconstructable

decision_rules.no_trace: If no causal trace exists → DENY (opaque decisions prohibited)
decision_rules.unfaithful_rationale: If rationale diverges from actual logic → QUARANTINE for correction
decision_rules.unrenderable: If explanation cannot be presented to user → QUARANTINE until rendered
decision_rules.excessive_cognitive_load: If explanation exceeds user comprehension → simplify before delivery
decision_rules.no_contestation: If no contestation pathway exists → DENY (right to challenge is mandatory)

validation_criteria: Causal trace exists and is complete
Rationale faithfully represents actual decision logic
Explanation is renderable in user-appropriate format
Cognitive load of explanation is appropriate for audience
Contestation pathway is available and accessible
sections.description: Framework defining how to ensure every AI decision has a causal trace, faithful rationale, renderable explanation, and an accessible contestation pathway for affected parties.

sections.theoretical_basis: Proportionality Principle (EU Charter Art. 52; ECHR case law) + Privacy by Design (Cavoukian, 2009) + Data Minimisation Principle (GDPR Art. 5(1)(c))
what_to_measure: Action impact magnitude on learner/data subject
Means-ends proportionality (is the action justified by its goal?)
Reversibility factor (can the action be undone?)

measurement_principles.least_intrusive: Always choose the least privacy-intrusive means to achieve the educational goal
measurement_principles.reversibility_preference: Reversible actions are always preferred over irreversible ones
measurement_principles.harm_asymmetry: Potential harms weigh more heavily than potential benefits in borderline cases
measurement_principles.progressive_disclosure: Collect minimum data first, request more only if pedagogically necessary

decision_rules.disproportionate_action: If impact exceeds educational benefit → DENY
decision_rules.irreversible_harm: If action has irreversible consequences → DENY unless pedagogically critical AND consented
decision_rules.privacy_violation: If less intrusive alternative exists → require justification for more intrusive choice
decision_rules.harm_threshold: If harm risk level exceeds threshold → QUARANTINE for human review

validation_criteria: Impact magnitude assessed for all affected parties
Means-ends proportionality justified
Reversibility factor calculated
No irreversible harm without explicit justification
Privacy minimisation principles applied
sections.description: Framework defining how to ensure system actions are proportionate to their educational goals, minimize data exposure, and prevent irreversible harm.

sections.theoretical_basis: Epistemic Justice (Fricker, 2007) + Evidence-Based Practice (Sackett et al., 1996) + Epistemic Injustice (Testimonial & Hermeneutical)
what_to_measure: Evidence existence for all claims and decisions

measurement_principles.no_blind_spots: Actively check for knowledge that may have been systematically excluded
measurement_principles.evidence_grounding: Every claim must have traceable evidence
measurement_principles.sufficiency_threshold: Evidence must meet minimum threshold before conclusions are drawn
measurement_principles.epistemic_humility: Acknowledge uncertainty rather than fabricating confidence

decision_rules.no_evidence: If no evidence exists for a critical claim → DENY the decision
decision_rules.insufficient_evidence: If evidence is below sufficiency threshold → QUARANTINE for more data
decision_rules.excluded_knowledge: If systematic knowledge exclusion detected → flag for review and correction
decision_rules.unsound_inference: If knowledge execution is logically invalid → DENY and require re-analysis
decision_rules.uncertainty_disclosure: If significant uncertainty exists → it must be disclosed in the decision rationale

validation_criteria: No systematically excluded knowledge detected
Evidence exists for all critical claims
Evidence meets sufficiency threshold
Inference chain is logically sound
Uncertainties are disclosed
sections.description: Framework defining how to ensure decisions are grounded in valid, sufficient evidence and that no relevant knowledge is systematically excluded from the reasoning process.

sections.theoretical_basis: Accountability Principle (GDPR Art. 5(2), Art. 24) + Principal-Agent Theory (accountability chains) + Algorithmic Accountability Act concepts

measurement_principles.traceability: Every decision must be traceable from input to output
measurement_principles.responsibility_assignment: Every decision must have a clearly identified responsible authority
measurement_principles.policy_linkage: Every decision must reference the governing policy that authorised it
measurement_principles.immutability: Audit trail must be tamper-evident and archival-grade

decision_rules.incomplete_trace: If decision trace is missing mandatory fields → QUARANTINE until completed
decision_rules.no_authority: If no responsible authority can be identified → DENY
decision_rules.no_policy: If no governing policy is referenced → QUARANTINE
decision_rules.tampered_trace: If trace integrity is compromised → DENY and escalate to human review
decision_rules.archival_failure: If trace cannot be archived → flag for remediation

validation_criteria: Decision trace schema is complete with all mandatory fields
Responsible authority is identified and recorded
Governing policy is referenced and applicable
Trace is archival-ready and tamper-evident
Accountability chain from decision to human authority is complete
sections.description: Framework defining how to guarantee a complete, tamper-evident audit trail with clear accountability assignment for every automated decision.

sections.theoretical_basis: Non-Compensatory Decision Theory + Deontological Ethics (Kant) — some violations are absolute prohibitions + Lexicographic Ordering (ethics cannot be traded off against utility)

measurement_principles.non_compensatory: A PASS on fairness cannot compensate for a FAIL on consent
measurement_principles.any_fail_veto: Any Hard Veto FAIL from any pillar triggers veto for the entire action
measurement_principles.aggregate_risk: Even if no single pillar fails, high aggregate risk may trigger quarantine
measurement_principles.remediation_first: Before denying outright, check if remediation is possible

decision_rules.hard_veto_fail: If ANY upstream Hard Veto (HV) pillar returns FAIL → VETO (absolute)
decision_rules.soft_veto_accumulation: If 3+ Soft Veto (SV) pillars return FAIL → QUARANTINE
decision_rules.aggregate_risk_threshold: If aggregate risk score exceeds 0.70 → QUARANTINE even without individual failures
decision_rules.remediation_available: If remediation options exist → issue QUARANTINE with remediation directives
decision_rules.no_remediation: If no remediation possible → issue DENY
decision_rules.iterate_until_stable: Re-evaluate after remediation until all signals stabilise

validation_criteria: All upstream ethical signals received and evaluated
Non-compensatory veto logic correctly applied
Aggregate risk score calculated
All constraint violations identified
Remediation requirements catalogued where applicable
sections.description: Framework defining how to aggregate ethical signals from all upstream assessments (legal, purpose, consent, fairness, explainability, proportionality, epistemic, accountability) and enforce veto power over non-compliant actions.

sections.theoretical_basis: Ethical Governance by Design + Value Sensitive Design (Friedman & Hendry, 2019) + Interoperability Standards (ethical constraint propagation)

measurement_principles.constraint_propagation: Ethical constraints must be faithfully propagated to all downstream agents
measurement_principles.agent_specific_packaging: Each downstream agent receives constraints in its native format
measurement_principles.no_constraint_loss: No ethical constraint may be dropped during handoff
measurement_principles.actionability: Downstream agents must be able to act on the constraints provided

decision_rules.incomplete_compilation: If any upstream assessment is missing → handoff BLOCKED until complete
decision_rules.constraint_coverage: All downstream agents must have their required constraints covered
decision_rules.hard_gate_passthrough: All veto decisions must be explicitly communicated in handoff
decision_rules.remediation_passthrough: Active remediation directives must be included in handoff

validation_criteria: All upstream ethical assessments compiled
Constraint summary covers all ethical pillars
Permitted action boundaries clearly defined
Each downstream agent has agent-specific constraint package
No ethical constraints lost in handoff packaging
sections.description: Framework defining how to package all ethical assessments into a clearance specification for downstream agent consumption, including constraint summaries and permitted action boundaries.
